In engineering problems, I like that the science is not everything, questions starting with "should" always depend on conditions. I would say that safety wise, running may not be best. Instead, as mentioned, physics, or mostly just math, tells us we should go home as fast as possible. In practice, that means fast without falling into puddles, slipping and falling, causing an accident etc. Walking quickly is usually best, but not if the roads are really slippery. Just walking would be better. However, one doesnt need any engineer or scientist for that. Intuitively, we know all of this and take it into consideration. In more complex problems, this is less intuitive and we should think practically about all other problems. Not just the science. I have a tendency to get bogged down in the science sometimes. Many of my engineering colleagues get frustrated because of that. sometimes, thinking simply is much more useful than very accurate scientific analyses

There is actually one case, when running isn't the best choice for getting from A to a dry spot B while it's raining: Assume running from A to B takes so long, such that the rain will stop before you reached B. Then the amount of water from above will always be the same, because you get drops as long as it rains. So the only thing you can minimize, is the water from beside by walking slower.

But if you walk slowly enough, your trojectory and that of the raindrops won't intersect on your side, so if the rain is falling straight down, moving slowly enough makes it so you only have to deal with rain falling directly on top of you, depending on your body shape and clothing, and in some cases we can assume that, depending on your clothing, the amount of wettness you can achieve from rain only hitting you from one angle will reach a kind of maximum saturation reguardless of speed, thus minimizing rain hitting you from any other direction would minimize resulting wettness even if you spend longer in the rain.

Of course then there is the fun one; if the wind blows towards your destination, you can eliminate rain hitting from the side by matching the speed of the wind, but if it's blowing from any other angle, or your route requires turning, the options are far more limited, so you should just run.

output:

Run on rain wetness = 9.4
code:
def ammount_drops walk_speed
rain_speed=9.0 #meters per second
adms=85 # ammount of drops per meter per second
person_depth=0.35
person_height=1.7
x=-4.0
xfinal=30.0+person_depth/2
dt=0.01
drops=[]
how_wet=0
while x<=xfinal
(dt*adms*xfinal).to_i.times{
drops<<{x: Random.rand()*xfinal, y:2.5} #random horizontal pos, 2.5m high
}
drops.each{|d|
d[:y]-=rain_speed*dt
d[:floor] = true if d[:y]<=0
d[:wet] = true if d[:y]>0 and d[:y]<person_height and d[:x]>x-person_depth and d[:x]<x+person_depth
}
how_wet+=drops.select{|d| d[:wet]}.count
drops.select!{|d| !d[:floor] && !d[:wet]}
x+=walk_speed*dt
end

return "#{how_wet/adms.to_f}"
end

puts "Walk on rain wetness = " +ammount_drops(1.4)
puts " Run on rain wetness = " +ammount_drops(5.0)

Disagree, the amount of rain on top of you and in front of you are inversely proportionate. Going slower gets more rain on your shoulders because the drops that would hit your front instead fall on you. And going faster the drops that would fall on you simply end up on your front. In the end you get the same amount of total rain but it's simply more in front or on top of you depending on speed. This too is oversimplified because you will have considerably more rain splashing on your feet, shoes and legs/pants by going faster.

TLDR running faster will make you wetter overall, mostly pants/legs/feet from additional splashing

This calculation assumes that rain is falling perpendicular to the ground. It completely ignores the horizontal speed of rain carried by the wind.
This can be fixed by substituting the walking speed relative to the horizontal speed of the rain in place of walking speed relative to the ground. Angle also matters, you will also get wet from the sides unless you're walking parallel (or exactly opposite) to the wind. You will likely not be travelling in a line and wind will likely change direction over time, adding complexity to the problem.

Okay here's the real truth for the walk in the rain vs run in the rain question. In very simple english. :)

The amount of rain that lands on your head purely depends on the amount of time outside in it. therefore spending less time outside gets you rained on less. therefore you should speed up to spend less time outside.

The amount of rain you run into depends on distance travelled, assuming straight rain. This mean speed doesn't matter for those purposes. it seems that you get more water in your face when you run, but the amount doesn't actually change. The less time spent in the rain directly counteracts that effect.

Complications.

1) If you are travelling with the wind, you can reduce the amount of rain impacting you by moving at the speed of the wind. But that may not be enough to overcome the time difference. And that may be walking or running speed. and the wind may change direction or blow the wrong way.

2) If you are going to get completely soaked regardless (it's a long walk) then moving faster will cause more of a chill, due to wind chill effects. So you may be better off walking at that point, depending on air temperature.

3) this changes completely if you have an umbrella. if you have one, it will keeps the rain out of your face. in this case, slower can be better, as if you go too fast the umbrella will block less. And it will struggle with wind if you try and move too fast.

One thing I learned from my physics degree is that it's frequently helpful to consider the limiting cases.

In the limit where you run superhumanly fast, the raindrops are effectively standing still, so you only hit the ones that are directly between you and your destination - which is a fixed number. In the opposite limit where you're the one who's effectively standing still, you can get hit by an unlimited number of drops. While that argument alone isn't enough to prove there's no optimum speed in the middle (there isn't, for the reasons explained in the video), it's at least enough to convince you that while it may not be possible to run too fast, it's definitely possible to run too slow.

The advantage of focusing on limiting cases is that often they simplify the problem in ways that make it quicker to reason about, and easier to avoid making mistakes. In this case, it's easier for me to compare "running while the raindrops stand still" vs. "standing still in the rain", than it is for me to evaluate the situations of walking and running at various speeds through moving rain.

This sort of approach is useful in practical situations, and is a good trick for multiple choice questions, too. E.g., if someone asked: "Which keeps you driest? (A) running in the rain, (B) walking in the rain, or (C) they're the same". By offering you only those choices, they've ruled out the possibility that it depends on exactly how fast you walk vs. how fast you run. And since we can quickly say that walking at tortoise speed is worse than running as fast as the Flash, we can conclude that the only viable answer is A.

The flaw in this is that at lower walking speeds, rain hitting your chest is blocked by your head. Here, the rain coming from the top is partly identical with the rain hitting you from the side.
If you wanted to simplify the human geometry, you have to assume a slighly forward facing box.

- - - - -
- -
- - ----> V
- -
- - - - -|-----| = Δx

If the time it takes the human to move forward Δx is identical to the time it takes the rain to fall down the height of the human, the sideways rain will be 0 for the duration of the walk.

This is not a good enough model, sorry... The velocity at which you collide with the rain drops is also a variable to consider. If the droplets never break they can simply roll off of your clothing. The faster you go the more this will break their surface tension causing them to absorb into any woven type fabric. So if you do a mad dash you will likely be soaked through unless wearing waterproofs... If you go too slow you'll look like a wet dog. Maybe the solution is somewhere in the middle, however this is now a 3 variable problem, good luck with that :)

Then you slip and fall, now you're on the floor, stationary. If you aren't quick, you'll be getting hit my drops of rain from above every second, and trying to get up takes time, and it also enlarges your surface area if you get up hunched over.
Now. You can decide to wipe your now dirty hands or not, but that also takes a fraction of time. It would be better to do it while walking, not running because that would be uncomfortable.
However, now that you've fallen, you will probably walk slower in the rain, making your wetter by the second.

In conclusion, it would be faster if you had walked from Point A to Poiny B because you wouldn't have fallen.

Hmmmm dunno dude. This theory assumes all rain falls at the same consistency, density and viscosity. What if the raining clouds are sparse and moving quickly versus if they were thick and moving slowly? Sparse and quick moving clouds produce more horizontally heavy rain (don’t run), thick and slow clouds produce more vertically heavy rain (don’t walk). And what if it’s raining diagonally? Run with the grain, walk against it to minimise the amount of drops hitting you.

False: this fails to account for the fact that rain falling on the head cannot fall upon the sides, and so the top of the body has a shielding effect upon the sides of the body. In fact, the rain falling on the sides can be entirely eliminated by proper combinations of forward speed and body angle. This introduces a complicated nonlinearity into the system because the total amount of rain that hits the sides is actually a function of distance and speed for any given body angle, not just a function of distance.

ACT questions be like

so, basically, you have 4 numbers, those numbers give you 2 results, and you have to compare which result is better.

1. How much rain is falling in your head
2. How long the rain will be

multiply those two, and you'll get the wetness value for you'll be if you stay still.

3. How much extra rain will you get if you start running
4. How long will it take to get home

multiply those two, and you'll get the wetness value for if you'll be if you run for home.

Compare the result of those two calculations. If the wetness value that you'd get staying still is higher than the one of running (wvS > wvR) start running. If the opposite is true, stay still.


Of curse, you'll never get those numbers, and by the time you finish your calculations, you'll be completely soaked up, lol. But calculations similar to this one appear all the time in physics, so this is good training. Also, that's a nice way of seeing how mathematics is always present in everyday life, we just don't usually see it.

高校のとき、クラスで3グループ(走る派、歩く派、同じ派)に分かれてディベート大会して、めっちゃ白熱したわ。
わいは馬鹿正直に走る派にして、多数派の他の人らにコテンパンに論破されたな。
この動画で言われてた事は、同じように一通り議論に上がってて、俺も一貫して時間との比例を主張したけど、ダメだったな。
半ギレで、「じゃあ雨の中お前らちんたら牛みたいに歩くんか？？」みたいに言ったような気がする。10秒で着くのと、1000秒で着くのじゃ、前者の方が濡れんやろっ！って何の客観性もない主張してたな。
結局、結論は忘れたけど、とりあえず、この動画で若き日の俺が合ってたのが分かってめちゃくちゃ嬉しい。

I disagree with the final method.  The faster you go, the more rain hits you in the wetness per meter category. So, you can't necessarily just say minimize the time when doing so increases your wetness per meter.  Considering the parallelpiped and raindrops suspended in air, however, the horizontal movement of the rain is part of its horizontal skew, as is your movement speed.  The height is shortened by moving faster, but the horizontal dimension is lengthened by moving faster.  But, as you said, those volumes are the same.  I'd say this probably works properly if you have a vertically oriented rectangular prism moving through rain.

this got recommended to me LITERALLY when it was raining and i was wondering this

Assuming a uniform direction and density of the pouring of rain, the amount of rain that hits your body is equal to the area of your "rain shadow" on the ground added up over time, so that'd be the area of the projection of your 3D body on the 2D ground integrated over time. Assuming the rain is falling straight down, running would elongate the projection while decreasing the amount of time you would be under the rain. What is interesting is the projection elongation would only be rain that missed the top of you but later you ran into it, this would represent a row of water in-between you and your destination that would need to be displaced for you to get there regardless of what speed you are moving. The other source of water would be on top of you and would be relative to the amount of time you spend in the rain.

Wait but the analogy to the snowplow doesn’t make sense. When plowing snow there is a set, finite amount of snow to displace regardless of the time taken to plow it. The rain, on the other hand, is constantly replenishing.

Also this doesn’t take into account the fact that, looking down from above, the amount of vertical and slanted surface area exposed of a walking person will for sure be at least some amount smaller than a running person, due to the more exaggerated extension of ones limbs while running. You can see it in just the stick man drawings you have made in the video.

I opened this video bc I’ve been baffled about this ever since watching the myth busters episode where they try to actually test this, and despite attempts to control as many variables as possible and doing repeated runs to reduce noise, they kept finding that walking yielded less total moisture absorbed than running.

I am still confused as to why this discrepancy occurred—not to mention the fact that the “myth” exists in the first place (if the physical solution is so simple, why does the advice come about in the first place?). I must admit, my own subjective, nonscientific, non-proofworthy anecdotal experience does actually jive with the “feeling” that when I run a certain distance in the rain I end up “feeling” much wetter than when I walk the same distance. At least when the total distance in question is fairly short.

Annoyingly, this issue remains unresolved in my mind. Does anyone know if myth busters ever squared this paradox from their live experiment producing consistent, opposite results to the solution of the question raised here?
Basically: ¿How long do you want to be getting wet?

No, you are ignoring several important things.
The time dimension, which is relatively important. And by the same token: the notion of movement of the drops.

If you stay 15 seconds under the rain going at 600m/s, you will receive the dose of rain associated with the density of rain per cubic metre in relation to time, the whole multiplied by the ratio between your surface area in square metres and time (we therefore have 3 dimensions) which is also expressed in cubic metres.
(Basically, if we made a film of you walking and mixed the images together. Your presence would not be one moment, but several. You would be a black shape in length ;) and the rain would not be fixed but a kind of homogeneous veil).

So if you've got the rain dose of one cubic metre, then turn back, it's obvious that the rain will have come back. Since it is falling.


Thus, if we move instantly from point A to B, the quantity of rain will only be that present in the volume crossed.
Now if we stay 2 hours under the rain before moving instantly to point B, we will have the same amount of rain as in the other case, plus the amount of rain for 2 hours without moving below.

Now we can take into account the inclination of the rain in our calculations. The idea is to summarize a human to a series of simple parameters that describe him enough to be faithful to a real case.

We can reduce a human to its total surface, or rather its exposed surface. Its speed and exposure time, which mainly determine the amount of rain received from suspended rain (in L/m3) or the volume of water arriving on a given surface in a given time in L/s.
The two types of water measurement are related, but one is more practical than the other depending on the context.
It can be noticed that the higher the speed, the less important is the quantity of water arriving on the ground. If the speed is infinite, only the water in suspension matters. Conversely, if you are stationary, the water in suspension makes no difference: only the volume of water reaching the ground (on you: your surface) matters.

However, when taking all this into account, we always forget one thing: the water absorption capacity. Because once it is completely soaked, there is no point in avoiding water. But it's so difficult to soak your clothes, there is always an undergarment that is a little dry.
However, if you're going to face a tornado that has just crossed a lake... you might as well tell yourself: water is no longer your main problem.

You might wonder how fast you have to go to neglect the falling drops. -> Too fast for a human. But technically it's better.

The calculation should look like this:
(Your speed divided by the distance to go) = time underwater
V / D = T

So,
Your speed multiplied by the time in the rain (or the distance travelled in the rain) multiplied by the amount of water suspended in 1 cubic metre. Plus, your exposed surface area multiplied by the volume of water arriving on 1m2 of floor, all multiplied by the time you remain exposed.

Se = exposed surface area
V = the speed
T = the time in the rain
D = V*T
Dw = density of water suspended in 1m3
Vw = speed of water
Qw = Dw*Vw

D(m)*Dw(L/m3)+T(s)*(Se(m2)*Qw)

So if you are under a heavy rain with 0.2L of water in 1m3 in suspension, where the water is going at 5m/sec. It arrives on 1m2: 1L/s
That you go at 2m/s (7km/h~) and that you run 10m: you will stay 5s in the rain.
And you will have taken 7L. Or 7 bottles of water of 1L.
While going at 20m/s (70km/h) you will receive 2.5L and a nomination for the world record.
More realistically going at 4m/s.
You will stay 2.5s, which brings us to 4.5L.
4.5L<7L
Note that you cannot take less than 2L with and example.
So we have something like :
2L<XL<inf

Assuming you are 1m2 and the rain is falling straight. Or that your exposed area is 1m2 in total and the rain falls at any angle.

This explains why running is of real interest. Note that if you look at my equation, you can see that what matters most is the time you stay in the rain. Running also reduces this time. Of course you take more water per second if the rain doesn't come from above, but you reduce the time when it comes from the side and ultimately the total amount of water received.

If you're out in the rain, you want to get out of that situation. Nobody really cares about how much water you absorb, the real issue is getting to a comfortable place ASAP. I don't want to spend several minutes longer in the rain, walking slowly, if I could run home and get inside my house.

When you factor in the cold and the getting-to-a-comfortable-place factor, this is really a no-brainer. We live in a world of experience, not a world of measuring how many ounces of water we absorved.

Additionally, it depends on the weather. Sometimes you get caught by an escalating rainfall. In those cases, staying out longer will get you increasingly wetter as the storm increases. It can always get worse, and the person is often able to make some predictions about this.

Therefore, do what feels right. When you get inside, you can get a dry shirt anyway. Running even gets you warmer.
You also need to factor in the experience of being out in the rain longer than possible. Wetness isn't the only factor.

Actually the best way is running but because of another reason.
Due to our head being infront of the rest of the body while running, it wont allow the rain infront of your body to hit your body because it already hit your head. Total wetness (TW)=wetness (W)/sec(s) X time spend in rain(h) + wetness(W)/meter(m) X Meters traveled(d).
The formula is correct, but shouldn't there be accounted for evaporation? So it should be:
TW-evaporation=(W/s x h) - evaporation(E)/s x h + W/m x d
Evaporation depends heavily on factors like humidity, % of body wetness, clothing, temperature and air pressure. But taken an warm, dry, slightly rainy day as an example: if E>W/s x h, then it would be better to just walk like a turtle.

Mathematically you get wetter the faster you move, but you also get wetter the longer you spend in the rain.

One important thing to note is that when you are completely soaked, getting more wet is both impossible and no longer has an impact since your already so wet.

Basically if your going across the street to Joe’s house in the rain running is best, but when you are traveling equal to or greater than an undefined distance walking is more practical because you would avoid the rain hitting you from the side

this acts on the assumption that rain is falling vertically, if due to wind, rain is falling at an angle it can be better to move at slower speeds under some circumstances.
if the wind is blowing towards you, you still want to run as fast as possible, but if its behind you, by running at a slower speed which matches the horizontal speed of the raindrops you can prevent any hitting your sides and reduce wetness. Also worth considering is the fact that raindrops hitting your sides are more likely to roll off, rather than make you wetter. Consider the extreme case, covering the distance to the building in a fraction of a second - the equivalent of a sheet of water hitting you all at once at a great speed - clearly going to make you wetter than the same water dipping against you over the course of several seconds and mostly rolling off. Getting gradually more ridiculous, an incredibly tall and thin person, or one with a small umbrella that only covers their vertical cross section might be better off waiting for the rain to stop than moving and incurring a greater wetness.

This assumes no wind whatsoever. It remains true if you're facing wind, but if wind comes from your back and is strong enough, then the optimal speed is the speed of the horizontal component of the rain's speed vector. With simplified calculation, the threshold for strong enough is v2 > v1 * s / S where v1 and v2 are respectively the vertical and horizontal components of the rain's speed vector, s is the area of your body seen from above, and S the area of your body seen from the side.
Answer is obvious from video title.. Didn't watch.

Wrong, a snowplow doesn't care about speed only when the volume in front of it is still the same, but if you add the snow falling then the slower you go the more snow you move.

Rain is a very different animal, and your speed is directly relevant to your 'wetness per second' If you dash all the way home in one second - then you hit every drop in the horizontal on the way there. The benefit is that the huge rate lasts for only one second. It is true that those time and rate equations balance out pretty well in the horizontal so the vertical is often the tie-breaker - which of course goes to faster is better. On paper anyway. In reality, as it so often does, the answer is: it depends. Wind and rain levels, distance, how you're dressed - too many things to cover here. But people can usually figure it out on their own.
So basically if you've got to move out the rain fast you need to move. And if you'll move you'll get more water on you.

The assumption that you always get the same amount of water form the side, regardless of the speed is just wrong. Just try it. If you walk you barely get and rain on the side (if the drops fall perpendicular to the ground i.e. no wind). If you run you are soaked. Why? Because we are not perfect cube-shaped. Imagine a letter "T" moving horizontally in the rain. If moving slowly no water will get to the vertical part, as the "roof" covers it. But at high speed the droplets will wet even that part as in the T's frame of reference as the speed increase the angle of the rain gets stepper. What is showed in this vid is purely theoretical.

Lets assume that the quantity of rain that drops on you in a minute is equal with x. If you run home (or anywhere else you get covered) you will get x rain multiple with the minutes you run. Lets say 5 minute. So you get 5x. If you walk slow you may get 1/2 of x but it will be multiple with the number of minutes you walk, lets say 15 minutes. So you have 15x / 2 = 7.5x But there is the unbalanced factor of injury. In case you get one your x may be stady but the time= minutes you stand in the rain holding your leg in terrible pain will be increase proportionally to the agony of not ending up wet in a hospital. There fore you shouldn't go out while is raining in the first place

You assume that the speed does not change the amount of rain you catch from the front. Rain falls at ~10m/sec, if you move slowly in vertical rain a good part of the rain directly infront of you will fall to the ground, a part is blocked by your head (which gets soaked anyway). If you move fast you'll catch more of the rain infront of you on all your body.
Also getting wet on a body is not endless, clothing can only take a certain amount of wetness.

So if you move in a slower way that protects a part of your body, no matter how long you take you'll be less wet than if you reach the goal in half the time but all your body is soaked ;)

Mythbusters tested this experimentally and came to the conclusion that you should walk, not run, through the rain. They tested this by measuring the weight of water absorbed by cotton coveralls. When Adam and Jamey ran through the rain, their coveralls absorbed more water.

I wonder what accounts for the difference between the Mythbusters conclusion vs. Minutephysics' theory - maybe when water hits your clothes with a greater horizontal force the clothing absorbs more of the water. If the top of your clothes will be saturated regardless of which way you decide to commute, the speed at which you travel could determine how saturated the front of your clothes become.

Here is the 4-minute Mythbusters video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HtbJbi6Sswg

Just make sure nobody is confused

In this tutorial, the amount of rain drop is same everywhere

The word everywhere mean all places you can see, that's why it's same.
Which mean the amount of rain drop above you is always the same, and it also mean the rain drop in front of you is always same, because the amount of rain drop is same everywhere, so because the amount of rain drop is same everywhere, that's why running and moving or stop in rain will still give you same amount of rain drop.

Now, the amount of rain drop is same, but rain drop is falling on you.
So if rain drop falling on you in one second is 2, then in 2 second It's 4. So the amount of rain drop you get is increase by the time pass, which mean you the less amount of time you stay in the rain the less amount of rain drop you will get, and your goal is have least amount of rain drop on you.

That's why you have to run, because it's reduce the time the rain give you raindrop.

If you are still confused, Just remember
"Amount of rain drop is different in different places" does not exist, only time exist, got it?

Long explanation to say something that a lot of people do anyway

What the creator didn’t think about was the fact that you move more on the y-axis when you run, as while running you reach higher and lower vertically. There is also water kick-up as I will call it, which is when you drag water off of the ground with your feet and into the air, some of it landing on the elevated or grounded leg. Since force = mass x acceleration and your leg has most upward acceleration while being lifted off the ground while running, the water-kickup factor is maximised while running. This will result in more water landing on you. The creator also didn’t account for splashing, and since force = mass x acceleration, obviously downward and forward acceleration of the leg is greater while running, but your knee is bent to a more acute angle while running, meaning more rain falls on it from the top, making it more massive. This results in a much stronger splash force, which only wettens yourself more. This also applies to your arms. Although your arms don’t come into contact with the ground, they will rub against your body more frequently while running, only spreading water faster. Since they are going back and forth so quickly, they are moving more distance horizontally - one could say almost double. This only gives them more time to run into or back into water. The arms are also at a more acute angle, meaning more water will land on them from the top.


Just one more thing - falling. Since balance = center of gravity/base of support, you are more likely to fall while running. This is because your center of gravity moves faster, not just because you are moving faster but because of your body leaning, and your base of support is moving faster and is less steady and supportive. While falling, you will come into contact with much more rain, and you come into contact with your height x width of rain area on the ground. Assuming you don’t get up instantaneously, you are allowing your clothes to absorb the water very quickly. Your knees and hands will also get wetter while you stand yourself back up again.


In actual conclusion, you may end up getting less total water on you while running, but you will have less water everywhere, head to toe. If you walk, you will have wetter hair and shoulders, but less water is likely to get on your arms and legs, and you are significantly safer.

I got indirect evidence that running is better (sometimes). I with my friend got under super heavy rain on a way from university to underground station. Its about 800 meters long (half a mile). And we were only wearing polo shirts and light trousers during the rain. So we beat it, but calculated pace when we almost got non raindrops. When we got to underground station we were almost dry (with light wet drops on shoulders), when everybody from our university (who tried other strategies) were almost wet till the last tread.

The fact is - clouds are moving, and there are gaps between clounds sometimes. And sometimes you can be so lucky that it can get between clouds in that gap and pace it your direction is the same as clouds are moving. When we ran we get to a point when cloud are in front of us and if you make one more step faster then you should - you get rain over your face and if you move slow enough- than rain hits your back.
If you see rain “waves” and you have no shelter to hide - try run between that “waves”. It works, but only ones I was so lucky that direction of rain waves were the same that I moved

This video is on the premise that raindrops have a perfect perpendicular motion to the ground ... That is false. If that were the case, having an open window on a flat wall with no window sill should not have any or should always have a relatively proportional amount of water inside the house based on the amount of overall rain fall forecast.

That is not the case.. since wind plays a factor.. If I were to run in the direction of the wind and the wind was strong enough to force rainfall in its direction, running has the most chance of avoiding the most amount of water. On rainy days with wind, even a window where rain should never creep in can have a lot of water seep inside. and this is due to wind..

Conclusion: Umm.. running is the obvious answer even without the need for you to know analytical geometry lessons XD

i dint think ur reasoning isn't very accurate because lets take this problem to basic shapes  because as u change the shape the amount of surface area that the rain can hit varies also. so let's put our guy in a box. the more that box has a smaller top section area compared to its side section area will make it be less wet if it goes slowly in the rain because the rain will be hitting only the upper section while the faster it goes the rain will be hitting more of its side too.  now lets take it up to a max and say that box was a vertical 2D plane, if that plane moves slowly transversally the amount of rain hitting its top will be negligible and very little rain will be hitting the side while the faster it moves the amount of rain hitting the side will be greater. so better walk unless ur in a square cubic box.

BUT if the rain is falling diagonally (which it does most of the time because of wind) things are a bit different.

If the wind is coming from your front (assuming you are looking at the place you want to go) you'll still have to run as fast as possible but will just get extra wet.
If the wind is coming from your side you will also still have to run as fast as possible and will get extra wet.
This applies to anything in between too, so if you T-Pose and the angle in which the wind is coming from is anywhere in front of your arms you are unlucky and get extra wet while still having to run as fast as possible.

However if the wind is coming from behind your arms when T-Posing you are lucky.

You can either still run at full speed and get a little less wet than you would get if the rain came from straight above you or calculate if it makes sense to walk slower.

If the wind is coming from straight behind you at the exact same speed as your running speed you will end up not hitting any rain from the side, but only from the top. If you're already running at your full speed and the wind is exactly your speed that is the single best case that could have happened to you after remembering to take your umbrella with you.

If the wind is coming from straight behind but is slower than your max. running speed then you might consider slowing down to the speed of the wind. Going at the exact same speed and direction as the wind always means no rain at all will hit you from the side. But slowing down also means more rain will hit you from above. So you can either decide which is more important for you, avoiding wetness from the side or from above. Or you can say I hate all wetness equally and calculate the proportion between your frontal area and your top down area. The bigger your frontal area is compared to your top down area the better it is to slow down.
If the rain isn't coming from directly behind you but partly from the side and partly from behind you can add the part from the side to the amount that always hits you from the top.

But I'm not going deeper into the calculations cause phone keyboards are cancer. Maybe we'll get another video showing you how to actually calculate your optimal speed in the case of diagonal rain which is probably more realistic than straight from above rain.

Usually when people run they also slightly lean forward. Assuming the rain falls straight down, this means that the area on which rain from the top can fall increases. So depending on how straight you run, it might actually be worse to run. However, the angle of the rainfall might differ because of factors like wind. If the rain is falling in an angle towards you, then running while leaning forward will actually decrease the area of rain from the top, making running the far superior choice.

What you should do in the rain isn't determined by how many raindrops are going to hit you. The approximate amount is going to be more or less the same. What other effect your actions have on you, your life, and your immediate future are far more important than whether you collide with more water, especially since in an amount of rain where this could even be relevant, everything is going to get as soaked as it's going to get, and not much more. Basically, is it really cold outside and you want to run because it's warm inside, and to increase your internal temperature? Then run. Are you having some sort of trouble with respiration that the rain itself isn't changing? Walking is probably a better idea to keep from overexerting yourself. Are you really tired, and barely have the energy to walk, let alone run? The answer is simple. Do you need to get wherever you're going by a specific time, which you are worried you will not make? Maybe run. All of these factors are more relevant than "how much water?"

This is incomplete science. The rate of rainfall on your surface area changes as your speed changes because the angle of rain contact changes.


Your speed affects the angle at which the rain hits your front, which also affects how much rain hits your front. This is the same reason direct sunlight causes summer and angled sunlight causes winter. If you are standing still, the angle of rain contact on your front is zero, so no rain hits your front. If you run the same speed as the rain is falling, the angle will be 45. If you run run like the Flash, rain will hit you near 90 degrees and you will dodge any new rain falling from the sky. This is also why snow (without wind) looks like it is falling at an angle when you are driving in a car. Winter is cooler because the same amount of sun is spread over more surface area because the angle is smaller, like standing still or walking slow. Summer is hotter because sunlight hits the earth at 90 degrees or some other steep angle, like running in the rain. So, running faster increases how much rain hits the front of you. The rate of rain, such as ounce per second per square inch increases as surface area increases (due to the speed of the runner). As this rate increases, however, your travel time will decrease. Think about it like this: If you stand still, all the water above you will hit you. If you run light speed, none of the water above you will hit you, but all of the water in front of you will hit you, and it will hit at 90 degrees to your front surface. The only reason this would get you more wet is because your front has more surface area than your top.

This analysis is incorrect. Your velocity relative to the velocity of the raindrops as they fall is important. The rain is moving faster than you are, so the relative vectors change as your velocity increases. More raindrops will hit you on the top of the head if you are moving slower than you could ever run into from the side. The vectors balance out at approx. 10m/s, or the estimated terminal velocity of medium to large-sized raindrops. It's only at THAT point that a change in your velocity, plus or minus, can be described in terms of limits.


Think of it THIS way - If you stood perfectly still, every raindrop falling in your vertical column would land on you for as long as it was raining and for as long as you stood there, regardless of whether you have a destination or not. As you move forward, if you're moving slower than 10m/s, every raindrop you dodge at the back is replaced by the one you run into at the front ONLY because you're moving slower than the raindrops are falling. Once you exceed that speed, you'll hit raindrop from the side, but ONLY on the front, and only in the horizontal column for as far as you travel. In fact, if you move at an infinite speed, you will only hit the raindrops that are directly in front of you, which would obviously be fewer drops than if you stood perfectly still or moved REALLY slowly. If the two scenarios are going to be equal, then they must be equal at the extremes as well as the limits approach infinity or zero.


It's actually even more significantly complex of a calculation than what's being described here, as it's not about the raindrops that hit you, but the rate at which they miss. As you approach the velocity of the raindrops, you will get hit by fewer. At 10m/s the bubble of raindrops that potentially MISS you is largest.


The catch is that there is no scenario in which the number of raindrops that miss you is infinite, or the number that hit you is zero. This is the part that confuses the issue and is an indicator that the solution is less straight forward.

How to stay dry in the rain:
1. Stay from point A. Dont go to point B yet.
2. Use Time until the rain stops.
3. From point A use Walk to travel to point B. Dont use Run because the rainwater will go all of your body.
4. After using Walk through point B, you stay Dry.

A + Time = 0 Speed + A + Walk × Travel = B

I know this is an old video, but I'm glad I ran into it because I looked through a hundred or so comments and I haven't seen one particular solution (I didn't check all the comments so I may have missed it): The other way to solve this problem is with boundary conditions. In case 1 you stand in the rain forever and get infinitely wet. In case 2 you run from A to B infinitely fast and you get wet by the amount of rain in the you-shaped volume you run through. Case 2 represents the minimum rain you could encounter and case 1 represents infinite rain. It's logical to expand and say that moving faster will get you less wet than moving slower.

Not the full truth, because of the "umbrella effect" (if you are standing still you get no rain on you from the side). This effect also holds true for slow movement. In essence your upper body is like an umbrella (if you had an actual umbrella you would eliminate all rain from above, and add none from the side for 0 total). So while in most cases moving as quickly as possible is best, there is a short distance at which moving slowly, because it utilizes your upper body umbrella effect, adds zero rain from the side and gives the lowest net total.

I agree with all of the math shown here, but I think that one factor is being overlooked. When walking, a person's posture is mostly vertical; their head and chest are directly above their feet and their legs are not swinging back and forth very much. However, when running, a person tends to lean forward, their legs swing back and forth a great amount, as do their arms. This causes their horizontal surface area to be greater, which means that when running, the rate at which water hits the person from overhead will be greater than the rate for when the same person is walking. I'm not sure how significant this would actually be in practice, but its something to think about.

You're assuming the rain falls vertically. However, because of the wind, it might fall diagonally. What would be the answer then?


There is still a part of rain which always falls on you and depends on time, although it is not only on top of you. If you run against the wind, there is an added horizontal amount of rain you run into, so the problem is the same as before.


However, if you have to run in the same direction as the wind, when you walk, less raindrops would hit you horizontally: if you ran in the same direction as the wind at the same speed, it would be as if you stopped with no wind, so rain only hits you vertically, so you should get faster until you reach the wind speed which moves the raindrops. Nevertheless, once you reach that speed, should you get even faster? If you did, you would sepend less time, so you would hit less raindrops vertically, but you would hit more raindrops horizontally, so I guess it would depend. I'll study the problem further on... I'll edit this if I find something out.

This video fails to take wind into account as moving with the wind at the right speed means that you won't get hit by any rain horizontally. The faster the wind blows the more advantageous this becomes as the horizontal rain becomes a bigger factor. For example if the distance to your house is 1000 kilometers and the rain blows 1000 kilometers a second in that direction, moving at the speed of light will still have you soak up nearly all the horizontal rain even though you dodge the vertical rain while moving with the rain will get you only one second of vertical rain with no horizontal rain which is bound to be less unless the rain drops fall at gravitydefying speeds.

This only assume that rain hits your body and stays in that place. In reality, if you're wearing some kind of clothing that will absorb water, water will accumulate and spread through your clothing the longer you're in the rain, whether it hits your head first or your front first. Take the extreme, if you stood in the rain for a very, very long time, your whole body would be wet and all your clothes saturated and likely dripping wet. On the other extreme, if you dashed through the rain very quickly, you'd be wet, but there's a good chance parts of your clothes would still be dry or much less wet, and nowhere near saturated. Run!

This video is wrong and draws the wrong conclusions off of their thought experiment. A certain amount of raindrops fall per second within a certain area. If you increase the amount of time, the number of raindrops to hit that area will have increased, therefore the things that resided within that area the longest would have been hit by more raindrops on average than those who stayed in that area the longest. That means time is a factor and thus speed is also a factor.

Wouldn't running also increase the amount of rain that falls on you vertically per second? Imagine you're viewing a person from directly above. You'd see more exposed surface area when they're running than when they're walking (arms swinging more, legs taking longer strides, etc). So then the total wetness equation(s) would involve two unique constants relating to this difference in vertical exposure between running and walking, and which option is better would be determined by a trade-off between how much additional rain strikes you from above when running and how much time you would save by doing so, right? Needs more data.

To simplify even further:
Every second, you increase in wetness by a flat amount whether you're moving or not.

In addition, for every foot you move, you increase in wetness the same amount no matter how long it takes.

Your wetness is the distance you move through the rain plus the time you're in the rain.

So to minimize wetness, you need to minimize both the time it takes and the distance you're moving.

If you're trying to get somewhere specific, the distance is fixed, so all you can do is minimize the time it takes, so you should move as fast as you can.

On the other hand, if you're just waiting for some event that happens at a specific time, then the duration is fixed and all you can do is minimize your distance, so you should stand still.
But time exists, if you run you'll be in the rain less...
It is easy to understand with limits approach. You walk extremally slow (particular distance) and you run extremally fast. From such point, we see: it is much better to run.

It's a great video but there's one bad assumption. You say the rain from the top is constant. But when you walk your arms are mostly straight down, minimizing their vertical profile. When you run, they swing, both catching more horizontal rain as they move, and catching more vertical rain as they increase the vertical profile of your arms. The same is true of your legs but to a much smaller degree. This changes the calculation, even if it doesn't change the result.

There's also something not considered. Even if you get more rain running, you start drying out faster by reaching your destination faster, so for example a 4 minute rain-walk leaves you with a wetness of x, while a 2 minute rain-run gives wetness y and a 2 minute head start on drying off gives wetness y-z. Even if y>x, y-z might be smaller than x.

Another potential variable to the equation could be that by running you minimise the probability of getting caught to a heavier storm.

Not sure I agree with the conclusion that rain hitting you sideways is constant regardless of your speed. This might be true in maths but in observation you get wetter on the side facing the direction of travel. This is like one of those things where science claims bees can't fly when obviously they can. The tradeoff is between increased wetness and the time reduced being in the wet after your reach cover. Obviously if you dash for cover and reach it quickly you'll get less wet than if you stand in the rain. This suggests the tradeoff is a curve where the advantage is only gained within a very short time and for longer times you might actually get wetter by running for cover.

FOR THOSE CURIOUS ABOUT THAT MATH: If you crudely model a person as a box moving relative to the rain, then the total wetness is given by the rain density times the volume covered by the surfaces that get hit by the rain (top and face) as the person moves. So the wetness is proportional to:

(area of face x horizontal distance) + (area of head x rain speed x time to shelter)

where the first term is the volume (i.e. base times height) of the "face" parallelepiped and the second term is the volume of the head parallelepiped. In other words,

wetness = "# of drops intercepted by both surfaces" = (rain density)[A_1*d + A_2*v_rain*(distance/v_run)]

so the faster you run, the less wet you will get because the second term will shrink. Keep in mind, however, that we've assumed that the rain is falling straight down.

No, your explanation is not correct.  1. You choose not to move and you get wet on all sides.......the longer you stay in the rain, the wetter you get.....that much is true. 2. You choose to move forwards  your top gets as wet as before, your front gets wetter and your rear gets less wet (that difference in wetness is taken up by your front). 3. If you can move forward fast enough where your speed is a significant percentage of the speed at which the raindrops are falling, you may be able to keep your rear completely dry.  I can physically demonstrate the above by keeping the rear windscreen of a car dry whilst driving it through rain at about 80 kms/hr.

Modelling raindrops as stationary is incorrect in this context. The analogy with snow plough fails because the mound of snow is constant over time, but the amount of raindrops as a function of time, isn't.
Just imagine dragging a large bucket past a waterfall. If you drag it along really slowly, more water will accumulate than if you quickly drag the bucket past the waterfall.
Hence, the amount of water falling onto the bucket- or the number of raindrops hitting you- will be less if you run, given you plan to cover the same horizontal distance either way.

Can't you avoid even more rain by angling your body forwards? If you hold an umbrella and stand still, there's a rectangle under the umbrella that receives no water. i would say walking is still better due to surface area. when people run they dont just run like a stick, they lean forward increasing the area in which things (in this case water) can hit it. so if you start at point A and start running, by the time you get to C, B would have hit you twice.

start at A. starts moving, B hits my head, keeps moving, C hits my head and B hits my back. this will continue all the way down. so that means that by the time you get to the area in which you are trying to go to, you will have double the amount of rain from above you hitting you than walking, sense walking is usually relativity strait up and down.

the water in front of you is consistent all the way through, like you said. so all that is determining how wet you get is the surface area in which you lean and speed. i will always say walking is better due to experience sense im outside almost every day.

wetness per second..😒 how do you even measure wetness??

running will increase the wet cloth area because depending on speed raindrops can reach more areas on your body
to visualize imagine running with an umbrella pointed directly up.
the umrella will protect you from from getting wet clothes only up to the point when your horizontal speed is fast enough so that in the time a raindrop needs to fall ~2m (from the top of the umrella to your feet) your horizontal speed covers the distance from your umbrellas rim to you clothes.
Example:
D (rim to clothes) : 0,3 m
H : 2 m
0,3/2=0.15 -> if you run at 15% of the speed of the raindrops they will reach your toes

another thing to consider is the area thats getting wet, the clothes that are protecting it and how sensitive that area is to cold/getting wet
wet head and shoulders arent as unpleasant as a wet breast and legs

also the angle of the impacting raindrops is kind of important since its responsible for wether the drop soaks into your cloth or deflects to the ground

But you also need to consider that the faster you're moving, the more likely you'll be to slip out. This will make your front body (stomach etc.) more wet due to the water on the ground, especially if you fall into some puddle, wich will cause you to be as wet as it gets on the frontside, considering the splash effect. Also, by the time you got up again, the rain will have an impact on your back and possibly the head as well. And due to the not fully restored mental presence because you've just gotten up again, you can expect yourself to have a slight walking-input delay.

At the end, there is no specific answer to this question because walking speed in rain depends on a number of environmental factors, such as puddles or also the sort of clothes you're wearing, the ground you're walking on, and also wheather (no pun intended), the rain is just coming from above or also from the sides. Most of the time however, I would prefer walking.

Here is a possible explanation:
In this video, you assume that how wet you get is proportional only to the column of rain that you intercept. In reality raindrops might not be absorbed by cloths but bounce off - the slower you walk, the more likely it is that raindrops bounce off because they come in slower overall and at a more shallow angle. So the faster you move, the higher the percentage of that column of rain you intercept.

Good explanation, but that's only correct for no wind conditions. When there is wind, the correct relation is:

W = a*t + b*l v - u l*t

Where: W = total wetness, a = vertical wetness per second, b = horizontal "wetness per second", v = your speed, u = wind speed, t = time.

Notice that when the wind has the same speed of you, you won't be horizontally wet, as expected.

Total amount of wetness=(Ah*Vx+Ab*Vz+Ab*|Vp-Vy|)*(S/Vp)   Vp- the velocity of running (which direct is the same as Vy), Vx- the raining velocity of x direction (doesn't matter how you r running) , Vy - the raining velocity of y direction (which is same as people running), Vz - the raining velocity of z direction (doesn't matter how you r running) , Ah- the area of head and shoulders, Ab - the area of body. So the result shows that, how much you get wet, depends on the velocity of the rain in different direction and your running speed regardless the area of head shoulders and body. If the Vy >> Vx , then the closer your running velocity to Vy, the less you getting wet; if Vx >> Vy, try as fast as you can. However, practically, run fast!!! If the rain is going to be brief, or you are a long way from shelter, then walking (or standing still) is probably better in order to minimise your distance covered while it's actually raining.

There's also the question of how fast you dry - water doesn't just hit you and accumulate until you're saturated - some of it runs off; some of it evaporates; and some soaks deeper until it reaches an equilibrium point. If you're running faster than the rain is falling, then your front is getting wetter faster than your top is, so if you were drying fast enough to not get soaked, you may no longer be. The actual break-even point comes sooner since water doesn't just stay on the surface it first touches, so if you're standing still, you can dry from your front even as you get wet on top...

If the rain is blowing in the direction you want to go, matching its horizontal speed can beat running at top speed. Particularly for a very tall thin shape.

For example, suppose you're a 10cm wide x 2m tall rectangle with a house 10m to the right of your position. The rain is blowing at a 45 degree angle towards the right. If you match the speed of the rain, you get rain_density * 10m/rain_speed_x * 10cm of water. If you double the rain's speed, you get rain_density * 10m/(2 rain_speed_x) * (10cm + 2m) of water. If you go infinitely fast, you get rain_density * 10m * 2m water. Of those three, the best solution is to match the rain's speed (unless rain_speed_x is quite small).

AHAH! but, if you are running faster you strike raindrops with greater force, as such if you are wearing say, a woollen jumper, low velocity rain drops at a shallow vector may glance off or not penetrate into the wool. But running into the drops the relative velocity is greater and the vector at which they hit the wool is deeper, with a larger component heading into the wool. Thus, running may reduce the number of raindrops that hit you but not necessarily your overall wetness, as it is more likely that a rain drop collision will deeply penetrate into your clothing

I think it can be explained by the shadowing effect.  Rain that hits your head won't hit your crotch.  by running you expose parts of yourself to rain that ordinarily wouldn't get wet.  Next, soaked is soaked.  Your head will not get any wetter once it reaches a certain level of saturation.  If you have hair that saturation takes longer.  Providing you make your target before saturation occurs there will be minimal flow from the top to the lower regions.  You experience wetness as "how much of me is wet" not "how soaked is my head", therefore you feel drier when less of you is wet.  A simple towelling of the head is much easier than changing out of wet pants, shirt, etc. and natural body heat can restore a shirt to dryness fairly quickly if it is not a heavy fabric.
Therefore the ONLY time when running really works is if the wind is blowing in such a way that when you run you are leaning into the slant of the rain (restoring the minimal contact area).  You will expose your upper thights, and of course the splashing of your feet will wet your lower legs more if you don't avoid soaked ground, so it is a bit of a balancing act.  But that is the way I explain my experimental evidence.

TL;DR: Run with an angle so that your head is the only thing hitting the water, such that the front of your body will only hit the air left behind by the area your head has already cleared out. Basically don't push your chest into to water by staying straight up, rather run at a speed so that the rain "falls away" from your front as you move forward.

RUN NARUTO STYLE

Does nobody think about how when you lean, you will run into less water in front since the water already in front of you will fall "away" from your leaning body, thus all the rain you would normally WALK into would now be stopped while hitting your head from above, given that you run with the perfect leaning angle relative to your (and the wind's/rain's) horizontal velocity.

To put it in a very clarified logical point of view, consider the rain falling straight down and your body moving forward (standing vertically), if switch the point of reference from the ground to the person in question it would seem as if the rain is moving at an angle while falling down, regardless of whether it's your body moving or the wind carrying the rain. This means, assuming you were standing still with this reference in mind (your body as reference), leaning slightly forward (assuming you won't fall over) will give the rain less of a surface area to hit as your body is aimed straight against the rains motion, thus only your head being hit.
Now for the translation switching the point of reference back to the ground (or the air flow if you like a slightly more completely covering approach) it would now be clear that while running at an angle that matches the angle from the rain relative to your body you will run into slightly increased amounts of rain compared to that of standing still, but meanwhile completely neglecting the rain that would normally (in a walking scenario) hit you from the front. The extra amount of rain that'd touch you can be calculated with something as simple as a Pythagorean triangle.

When running on slippery surfaces though the potential consequences are obvious. There are multiple parameters here to take into account in choosing to run or not to run, including the shoes you are wearing, your background in ice skating and parkour, any precious cargo on you etc. etc. I'm sure Professor Gadget doesn't bother himself with these questions.

The total amount of rain that hits you determines your wetness. TOTAL is the keyword here. Now as far as covering a fixed distance from A to B, your speed will not effect the amount of rain that hits your head (from top) per second, HOWEVER your speed will determine how long you will have to stay under the rain for you to cover that distance, hence this variable (your speed) changes the total amount of rain that drops on your head from the top. The second thing you want to deal with is rain from the side, this works the opposite as rain hitting your head from the top because your speed will effect how much rain you run into PER SECOND, however it will not effect the total amount of rain that you will inevitably HAVE to run into over said fixed distance. What this means is that you do not need to consider the rain you run into from the side because the only variable that could effect this is the distance from A to B which is a constant that you cannot change. On the other hand, your speed is something you can control, and your speed determines how long you stay under the rain to cover a distance, so in a few words the less time you spend under the rain the drier you are. This video is actually wrong, in concept, and right in answer. Rain has a terminal velocity of 8 meters per second (about 18 mph). If you travel faster than 18 mph you get hit by multiple "columns" of rain from the side per unit length of rain drops, and if you travel slower than 18 mph you get hit by multiple "layers" of rain from the top per unit length of rain drops.

But, if you travel at 18 mph, you only get hit by one rain drop per unit length of rain drops. So yes, the right answer is to run, but only to reach a speed closest to 18 mph to stay driest by getting hit by the minimum amount of drops(for reference, a full on sprint would probably reach around 23 mph).

There is another factor to consider. As a theoretical mathematician (are the any other kinds?), I can be guilty of failing to notice the bigger picture. In this case, it is desirable to minimize the amount of water already on the ground that splashes up on you when you proceed. This "puddle-wash" is generally greater when running. I used to enjoy splashing around in my galoshes/Wellingtons, but it's been more than 50 years now. In "regular" footwear, I splash less puddle water on myself when walking. I suspect that's not only me. So walk or jog at as fast a pace as you can without splashing any additional ground water onto yourself. The fastest pace is to minimize the other unmentioned but implied criterion: "without dying of pneumonia within the month".

True, but only if the rain is falling perfectly vertically. If there is wind and the rain is coming down on a slant, you may end up getting less wet if you travel at the same horizontal rate as the rain is falling.

Also note, that if the rain is moving, let's say north, at 8 mph, and you are travelling north at 8 mph, you won't have any rain hitting you from the side. If you were travelling any other speed or direction, however, you would have rain from the side. Therefore, you would stay the driest if you moved north at 8 mph.

Well there is actually one more factor that has some importance...  As you move, especially the faster you move, you actually expose more of your body to the rain falling from above.  Think of it this way... if you are standing still, the total area exposed to the rain is roughly your head and shoulders.  As you extend your leg, the top of that leg is now exposed.  If you run faster, you probably take longer strides, extending your legs further, and exposing more area from above.

Is this significant?  I have no idea.  It probably is under certain rain fall conditions.

Oh and if you start to consider this... you also can't safely assume the rain is falling straight down either.  This problem just became very interesting....

Quick question.>>> so i am assuming through order of operations that the mathematical way to write that formula would be (a x b) + (c x d) = Total wetness, given that a= wetness per second, b= time spent in the rain, c=wetness per meter, and d=meters traveled. so to keep it simple we can assume that all values = 10. ergo >> (10x10) + (10x10) = 200 total wetness. now, if you were to compare the rate of which you were moving through the rain we know that certain value stay constant, A and D, however B (time spent in the rain) and  C (wetness per meter change). Given that i am moving at 2x the speed of my previous equation. i would spend half as much time in the rain, but receive 2x as much horizontal wetness per meter. now the equation would look something like this. [10 x (10/2)] + [(10x2) x 10]  >>= (10 x 5) + (20 x 10) >>> = (50) + (200) = 250 total wetness. so it would seem that a 2x increase in speed would result in a 25% increase in wetness. ergo, ill stick with walking.

it: Penso che il problema non sia "correre" o "non correre". il problema è la scelta di correre o la scelta di non correre. This video completely neglected risk assessment: why is getting wet bad? My guess is that it comes from the myth handed down by oral tradition that getting soaked by rain causes illnesses ranging from catching a cold to full-blown pneumonia. I live in an often-wet area north of Seattle, WA but in 35 years I have never gotten sick as a result of getting wet. On the other hand, I have broken my hip as a result of being in too big of a hurry while getting down from the driver's seat of a tall RV. I tried stepping down like on stairs instead of taking the time to turn around and climb down like on a ladder. It wasn't raining at the time, but that doesn't make my example off-topic because the point is that falling is more likely to hurt us than getting wet, and running on wet surfaces is more likely to result in slipping and falling than walking carefully.

So, the cabin is shielding the contents of the bed while you're moving, just as long as you're moving fast enough. It's just like what would happen in a calm, straight-down rain with your truck standing straight up with its front end pointed up. Part-2

2) Additionally, running, raises your metabolism. You breathe faster, heart goes faster, body temperature increases. You remain in this state of increased metabolism for a few or many minutes after you stop running. The effect of this metabolism increase is that you burn extra calories that you don't burn if you are walking.

Running, for two reasons.

Part-1

1) You do more work running. Walking, you don't "lift" the weight of your body (significantly) off the ground. You put all your weight on your stationary foot while it's on the ground, then move the leg that isn't supporting any weight. Your work is just moving your body laterally from point A to B.

Running,  You do the same work to move laterally from point A to B, but you also do the work of lifting your weight off the ground with each step.

            Fba=Front body area
            vx=Your x component speed
            vrx=Rain x component speed
            vry=Rain y component speed
            deltaS/vx=Time under rain
            u=Water mass per volume

Running is better. Look at the equation he gives and liken it to this one: 
TW = Wt*t + Wd*d
For simplicity's sake, let's assume that all raindrops are equidistant and Wt=Wd. Also, if distance (d) stays constant, that means Wd*d is constant, meaning that the only thing that will change TW is t. The smaller the time spent in the rain (t), the less wetness per second (Wt), and the less total wetness (WT). I hope that makes sense! :)

What I was referring to was that if you stand still, the water will only hit your head, but if you move, the water will hit your sides as well. And for the water to hit your sides, it has to be "travelling diagonally". Not saying that the drops themselves travel diagonally, but that they will be hitting you at an angle.

remember, the world has 3 dimensions...you will never remain dry on the sides, no matter how fast you run, because you are running horizontally. The point of contact is stretched with each drop. the drop hits you, but since it must change direction suddenly, it must stop at a point, and transition to the direction of which more force is moving. The rain hits you faster if you move faster, but you also get there more quickly. It has to do with the fact that you sweep out the same volume of rain on your side no matter how fast you run. Mathematically this is sound.

Mythbusters are entertainment, and as a result they aren't able to take into account a lot of variables or use basic rigor. Considering only the amount of water that hits you, running is better. Considering how wet your clothes become is a much more complicated problem.

Deleted my previous comments due to mistakes. Here's the equation for volume of water that hits you:

V=A_s*δ*d + (v_w*δ/v_p)A_s*d + (P/v_p)*A_t*d

A_t and A_s are top and bottom areas, v_p and v_w are sideways velocities of person and rain(opposing the velocity of the person), P is precipitation rate, d is distance travelled, and δ is volume of rain per unit volume of air.

Only two terms depend on the person's velocity and they both get smaller as velocity gets bigger, making it best to run.

I live in Florida and worked for many years outdoors. I learned quickly that wind definitely factors into this equation! If you are moving into the wind you will get a lot wetter than if you move in the same direction. Therefore if you are in a windy and rainy situation try to move toward cover that is with the path of the wind. Even if it is a greater distance you will be less wet!

It's better to realize that if you experience being as wet as possible at least once and also on a different rainy day invent a strategy to be as dry as possible, then you will have more knowledge that you can use for more things than if you start from the single one of two assumptions:

That it is better to avoid wetness, or better to avoid dryness.

Common sense solves this one if you think about it a bit. Just imagine that it's just pouring down rain almost showering and obviously the logical idea is to get out of the rain as fast as possible (=run). Same applies to every type of rain. Although different parts of your body get different amounts of rain if you compare walking to say riding a bicycle. Thighs and hands catch much more of the rain while cycling and head and shoulders more when walking.

Okay, for all you guys confused by the different outcomes:

BOTH RUNNING AND WALKING CAN BE BEST,
It depends on the situation.

What this video does not calculate is the speed of the raindrops hitting you.
If you run, OR the rain gets heavier, you get soaked because the raindrops will penetrate your clothing more.

So basically, walking keeps you dryer in light rain, running makes sure you get less wet if the rain is already intense enough to soak you by getting you out of the rain faster.

Mythbusters did this experimentally. This is the core logic behind it. There's tons of things that can make the experiment not reflect this logic. However, one should believe the experiment more accurately predicts one's outcome.

Things don't always work in practice as they do in theory. This video explains what would theoretically reduce the amount of wetness, whereas doing actual tests will determine what actually happens.

In 2003, on Discovery Channel, a Mythbuster program aired in which Adam and Jamie tested the "walk vs run in the rain" question. They set up an indoor course, 100 ft in length with artificial rainfall from overhead sprinklers (2-3" per hour).  They wore identical cotton overalls that were accurately weighed before and after a rain traverse. They each did two replicate determinations of walking and running through the rain course. They picked up more water running vs walking, by a factor of 2.

I also sometimes get caught in the rain while I'm out walking at night when it's so dark out that people who are more than 60 feet away from me can't even see that I'm there.

Actually, it depends on 3 factors... 

1) How cold the water and air temperature are. 
2) Where you are.
3) WHEN you are.

THAT feels extremely exhilarating. I frequently go out of my way to get into the woods while it's raining to take advantage of that situation.

Actually, if you move slower than the rate it takes a raindrop to fall from the height of your head to the ground you won't run into any raindrops at all. So if you walk slow enough you won't run into any droplets at all.

These calculations would be correct, If every single raindrop was falling straight down

In that case, the constant would not just be raindrops on the top of the head, but the constant would THEN be raindrops on the top of the head and partially on the front side. When you look at it that way you should also include your area surface from the front, because that is the part that will get wet when you are moving. To minimise this area you should actually walk sideways, but this will increase your area seen from the top. Since the amount of rain that you will run into is always the same, regardless of your speed (as discussed in the video), and the amount of rain that comes on top of you depends on your speed, I conclude that you should run sideways!

This also relies on the rain falling at a constant rate.  Obviously, if you start running while there is a little bit of rain you will get back to shelter quickly.  If you walk and the rain increases the rate at which it is falling you will get more wet than if you ran and took cover before it got worse.

A way to rough out this problem logically: if you stayed totally stationary, you would get infinitely wet, because you would never get to point B. On the other hand, if you moved infinitely fast to point B, you would get the minimum amount of wetness possible (whatever droplets are already between you and point B). So it would stand to reason that the faster you move, the more favorable wetness outcome would be.

Well, this methodology makes two assumptions:

1.) There is no wind to speed up rain hitting from front  2.) The line between you and shelter does not deviate from facing the wind

It overlooks some unrelated factors:

1.) Running prevents you from hugging yourself, increasing your surface area  2.) Running may make you slip and fall, wetting you  3.) Running creates splash, increasing rain that hits from front  4.) Running causes your feet to land with more force, making your shoes absorb more

Let's assume that you have an area from the front of 1 m^2. The rain is moving in the same direction as you are, at 1 m/s. If you walk at 1 m/s, you will not get wet on the sides; if you run at 2 m/s, you will get wet, but your head will only get half as wet. The velocity you have to run is a function of the velocity (including direction) of the rain.

You didn't factor in what happens when saturation point is reached; the extra water hitting the saturated area runs down the surface to an unsaturated place or it's lowest gravitational potential... Your head and shoulders get soaked, then the extra water dribbles down you and soaks the rest of you. This is ignoring adsorption and capillary action which would spread the water from the top of you all over the garment and those they are in contact with until saturation. Time permitting of course.

You forgot to factor in wind. Rain almost never comes in vertically. If the wind speed is faster than the terminal velocity of the droplets then you will get more wet from the side than the top (when stationary). If this is the situation then the speed differential between you and the rain is more important. In fact, If you travel in the same direction as the rain at the same speed as the rain then you will not get hit by any rain from the sides, only from the top regardless of time or distance.

Um....no. A hypothesis does not become a law, and a law never becomes a theory. A theory/hypothesis explains why something works, eg Darwin's theory of evolution, whereas a law is an observation of something eg Newton's 3 laws of motion. Experimentation does NOT create laws, nor does it "interpret" a theory. Experiments never interpret anything, it can only DENY something. That's why hypothesis are proposed; so that they can be denied. If you can deny it, it is taken as the BEST THEORY.

I arrived at the same conclusion but with different reasoning. My reasoning was to look at the 2 opposite extremes of standing still forever under the rain and running at infinite speed toward your destination. In the first case, you enter in contact with an infinite amount of rain (assuming the rain never stops, which isn't realistic...). In the second case, you enter in contact with a finite amount of rain, proportional to the distance to your destination.

When you're running, your surface area as observed from the sky is bigger, since your arms and legs are extended.   More surface area = more rain hitting you from the top.

And also consider the rain from the "side".   A clothed arm straight down in the rain for 1 minute will get hit by less rain that one swinging backward and forward twice a second, smacking into rain on both the backward and forward motion.

I think Mythbusters had it right, and your parallelepiped model is to simplistic.

Lots of people are bringing up the Mythbuster's tests, which seem to show the opposite. This is a classic example of a theory vs. test. However, the Mythbuster's testing wasn't covered by peer review and was, at best, poorly thought out. Alternately, this theory doesn't cover all the variables (horizontal rain, droplet size, evaporation via body heat caused by running, etc..). I think a real, reproducible, reviewed LAB test is required for this. Preferably at the expense of the US government.
